content.gameSubtitle: Astronaut Training Exercise ‚Ä¢ Mission Control Interface
content.emergencyScenario:
Your spacecraft has crash-landed on the lunar surface approximately 120 miles from the nearest lunar base. The impact has destroyed your mother ship and damaged most of your equipment. 

                    You and your crew are uninjured, but your survival depends on reaching the lunar base on foot. You must traverse the moon's harsh terrain with limited supplies. The lunar day will last approximately 14 Earth days, followed by 14 days of darkness. Surface temperatures range from 260¬∞F (127¬∞C) in sunlight to -280¬∞F (-173¬∞C) in shadow.

                    Your space suits are intact with 72 hours of oxygen remaining. Below are 10 items that survived the crash intact. Your crew's survival depends on choosing the most critical items to carry on your 120-mile journey to safety. Remember, every pound matters in the moon's low gravity, and you can only carry so much.
content.instructionsText: Rank these items from 1 (most important) to 10 (least important) for your survival journey. Consider oxygen supply, navigation, communication, and protection from lunar conditions.
content.dragInstructionsText: Arrange items by importance. Your decisions will determine mission success!
content.progressText: Arranging survival priorities... Lives depend on your choices.

expertPriorities: Oxygen is absolutely critical - without it, nothing else matters
Navigation and orientation are essential to avoid getting lost
Communication could mean immediate rescue if functional
Protection from temperature extremes is vital on the lunar surface
Some items that seem useful on Earth are worthless on the Moon

items.name: Two 100-pound tanks of oxygen
items.explanation: Most pressing survival need. Without oxygen, survival time is minutes.

items.name: 5 gallons of water
items.explanation: Prevents dehydration. Essential for 120-mile journey in space suit.

items.name: Stellar map of lunar constellations
items.description: Map showing star positions from Moon
items.explanation: Primary navigation method. Essential to find lunar base direction.

items.name: Food concentrate
items.explanation: Provides energy for long journey, though less critical than water.

items.name: FM receiver-transmitter
items.explanation: Possible communication with base, but requires line-of-sight on Moon.

items.name: 50 feet of nylon rope
items.explanation: Useful for climbing crater walls or tethering crew together.

items.name: First-aid kit with injector
items.explanation: Important for injuries, but special injector works through space suit.

items.name: Parachute silk
items.explanation: Can provide sun protection or carry items, but limited use on Moon.

items.name: Life raft with CO2 bottles
items.explanation: CO2 bottles could provide minor propulsion, but raft itself is useless.

items.name: Signal flares
items.explanation: Useless on Moon - no oxygen for combustion, no atmosphere to see smoke.

content.gameSubtitle: Maritime Emergency Training ‚Ä¢ Coast Guard Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
Your yacht has struck a reef and sunk in the South Pacific, approximately 1,000 miles southwest of the nearest land. You and your four crew members have managed to inflate a large life raft and are all uninjured.

                    The weather is calm with 3-foot swells, but storm season is approaching. Water temperature is 78¬∞F (25¬∞C). You're far from shipping lanes, and your last radio contact was 6 hours ago. Your emergency beacon sank with the yacht.

                    You managed to salvage 10 items before the yacht disappeared beneath the waves. Your survival depends on making the right choices about what to keep in your limited raft space. Search and rescue operations typically take 7-14 days in this remote area.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 by importance. Consider hydration, signaling for rescue, protection from elements, and sustaining life until rescue.
content.dragInstructionsText: Prioritize items for open ocean survival. Every choice matters!
content.progressText: Setting survival priorities... Your decisions could save lives.

expertPriorities: Signaling devices are top priority - being found is everything
Water is critical - dehydration kills in 3-5 days
Protection from sun and exposure prevents rapid deterioration
Food is less critical - humans can survive weeks without it
Stay with the raft - swimming or leaving drastically reduces survival odds

items.name: Shaving mirror
items.explanation: Best signaling device. Visible up to 20 miles on clear day to aircraft.

items.name: 2-gallon can of water
items.description: Fresh drinking water in sealed container
items.explanation: Prevents dehydration. Most critical after signaling. 3 days without water is fatal.

items.name: Emergency food rations
items.explanation: Provides energy, but humans can survive weeks without food if hydrated.

items.name: Plastic tarp (20 sq ft)
items.explanation: Catches rainwater and provides sun protection. Versatile survival tool.

items.name: 1 quart of 20-weight oil
items.explanation: Can calm waves around raft and create visible slick for aircraft spotting.

items.name: 15 feet of nylon rope
items.explanation: Secures equipment and people. Could aid in rescue or raft repair.

items.name: 2 boxes of chocolate bars
items.explanation: Quick energy but melts in heat. Less efficient than survival rations.

items.name: Fishing kit with line and hooks
items.explanation: Potential food source but unreliable. Requires time and energy to use.

items.name: Seat cushion flotation devices
items.explanation: Already in raft, so redundant. Could mark position if thrown overboard.

items.name: Shark repellent
items.explanation: Largely ineffective. Staying in raft is best protection from sharks.

content.gameSubtitle: Mountain Rescue Training ‚Ä¢ Wilderness Emergency Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
Your small aircraft has crash-landed in the Rocky Mountains at 11,000 feet elevation during late October. The pilot is dead, and the aircraft is too damaged to repair. You and three other passengers have only minor injuries.

                    The crash site is in a narrow valley surrounded by peaks. The nearest town is 50 miles away, but you don't know in which direction. Night temperatures drop to -20¬∞F (-29¬∞C), and a storm system is approaching. Snow depth is already 2 feet with more expected.

                    You're dressed in business clothing suitable for city weather, not mountain survival. The plane's radio is destroyed, but the emergency beacon may be working. Search and rescue could take 2-7 days in these conditions. You've salvaged 10 items from the wreckage.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 for survival importance. Consider shelter, warmth, signaling, and the decision to stay or attempt hiking out.
content.dragInstructionsText: Prioritize for extreme cold mountain survival. Choose wisely!
content.progressText: Evaluating survival priorities... Mountain conditions are unforgiving.

expertPriorities: Fire is life at high altitude - warmth prevents hypothermia within hours
Shelter from wind and snow is critical for surviving nights
Stay at crash site - searching expands search area exponentially
Signaling devices multiply rescue chances in vast wilderness
Calories and hydration maintain body heat and decision-making ability

items.name: Waterproof matches (4 boxes)
items.explanation: Fire means survival. Provides warmth, signaling, water purification, and morale.

items.name: Canvas tarp (20x20 feet)
items.explanation: Essential shelter from snow and wind. Can save lives first night.

items.name: Sectional air map of area
items.explanation: Shows location relative to towns and helps rescuers if you stay put.

items.name: Flashlight with 4 batteries
items.explanation: Vital for signaling aircraft at night and emergency tasks.

items.name: Fifth of whiskey
items.explanation: Fire starter, antiseptic, and trade value. Drinking it reduces survival.

items.name: Magnetic compass
items.explanation: Useful with map but staying put is safer than wandering in mountains.

items.name: 20 candy bars
items.explanation: Quick energy maintains body heat, but less efficient than other foods.

items.name: Newspapers (one per person)
items.explanation: Excellent fire starter and insulation inside clothing.

items.name: Loaded hunting knife
items.explanation: Useful tool but less critical than warmth and shelter items.

items.name: .45 caliber pistol (loaded)
items.explanation: Poor signaling device, dangerous if misused. Wildlife avoids crash sites.

content.gameSubtitle: Cold Weather Training ‚Ä¢ Arctic Emergency Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
Your research station in Northern Alaska has been destroyed by a severe ice storm. You and your team of five are stranded 80 miles from the nearest outpost. It's January, with 24-hour darkness and temperatures reaching -60¬∞F (-51¬∞C).

                    The storm has knocked out all communications, and your vehicles are buried under ice. Winds are gusting to 50 mph, creating deadly wind chills approaching -100¬∞F. You have basic arctic clothing, but the station's main supplies were destroyed.

                    The weather window for rescue flights is extremely limited. Your team must survive until conditions improve, which could be 5-10 days. You've managed to salvage 10 items from the wreckage before everything froze solid.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 for arctic survival. Consider protection from cold, maintaining core temperature, and avoiding frostbite.
content.dragInstructionsText: Order items for extreme arctic survival. Every second counts!
content.progressText: Calculating survival priorities... Arctic conditions kill in minutes.

expertPriorities: Shelter from wind is absolutely critical - wind chill kills in minutes
Maintaining core body temperature requires multiple heat sources
Signaling in 24-hour darkness requires special consideration
Calories are burned rapidly in extreme cold - 5000+ per day
Any exposed skin can suffer frostbite in under 30 seconds

items.name: Arctic sleeping bags (compressed)
items.description: Extreme cold weather sleeping bags rated to -40¬∞F
items.explanation: Essential for surviving sleep periods. Core temperature drops are fatal.

items.name: Portable camp stove with fuel
items.description: Pressurized stove with 5 days of fuel
items.explanation: Provides heat, melts snow for water, and enables hot food/drinks.

items.name: Signal flares (12 flares)
items.explanation: Only reliable signaling in 24-hour darkness and storms.

items.name: Four-season mountain tent
items.explanation: Wind protection is critical. Reduces effective temperature by 40¬∞F.

items.name: High-calorie rations (10,000 cal/day)
items.explanation: Extreme cold burns massive calories. Starvation accelerates hypothermia.

items.name: Emergency radio beacon
items.explanation: Works in clear weather but batteries fail quickly in extreme cold.

items.name: Cross-country skis
items.description: Skis with poles for snow travel
items.explanation: Movement keeps you warm but increases exposure risk. Stay put is safer.

items.name: 100 feet of rope
items.explanation: Can create guidelines between shelters in whiteout conditions.

items.name: Arctic first aid kit
items.explanation: Treats frostbite but prevention through warmth is more critical.

items.name: Survival knife
items.explanation: Useful tool but manual tasks in extreme cold risk frostbite.

content.gameSubtitle: Jungle Warfare Training ‚Ä¢ Tropical Emergency Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
Your military transport has crashed deep in the Amazon rainforest. The pilot is dead, and the radio is destroyed. You and four other survivors have minor injuries. You're at least 100 miles from any known settlement.

                    The jungle canopy is so thick that rescue aircraft will have extreme difficulty spotting you. Temperature is 95¬∞F (35¬∞C) with 98% humidity. Heavy rains occur daily, and the area is known for dangerous wildlife including jaguars, snakes, and poisonous insects.

                    Your uniforms are already soaked with sweat and rain. Every movement through the dense vegetation is exhausting. Rescue could take 7-14 days if your emergency beacon is working through the canopy. You've salvaged 10 items from the wreckage.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 for jungle survival. Consider protection from wildlife, disease prevention, signaling through canopy, and maintaining health.
content.dragInstructionsText: Prioritize for hostile jungle environment. Stay alert!
content.progressText: Analyzing jungle survival needs... Every item could mean life or death.

expertPriorities: Machete is king in jungle - creates shelter, signals, and protection
Water purification prevents deadly diseases - biggest killer in jungle
Signaling through triple canopy requires special techniques
Insects and disease kill more than predators - protection essential
Stay near crash site but improve position for visibility

items.name: Machete with sheath
items.explanation: Essential for movement, shelter building, and clearing signal areas.

items.name: Water purification tablets (100)
items.explanation: Prevents waterborne diseases - biggest killer in jungle survival.

items.name: Signal mirror
items.explanation: Best chance of signaling aircraft through small canopy gaps.

items.name: Mosquito netting
items.explanation: Prevents malaria, dengue, and other insect-borne diseases.

items.name: Waterproof tarp
items.explanation: Essential rain protection and can collect clean rainwater.

items.name: Jungle first aid kit
items.explanation: Treats bites, stings, and infections common in jungle.

items.name: Flare gun with 6 flares
items.explanation: Can penetrate canopy better than smoke, useful for rescue.

items.name: Military MREs (10 days)
items.explanation: Safe food source, though jungle can provide if necessary.

items.name: Military compass
items.explanation: Limited use in dense jungle where visibility is 10-20 feet.

items.name: 9mm pistol with 30 rounds
items.explanation: Poor jungle tool. Noise attracts danger more than provides safety.

content.gameSubtitle: Underground Emergency Training ‚Ä¢ Mine Rescue Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
A massive cave-in has trapped you and five other miners 2,000 feet underground. The main shaft is completely blocked, and it will take rescue teams 5-7 days to dig through safely. The mine's communication system is dead.

                    You're in a stable pocket about 50 feet long by 30 feet wide with 8-foot ceilings. Air quality is currently good but won't last forever. Temperature is 65¬∞F (18¬∞C) but humidity is near 100%. Water is dripping from several points in the ceiling.

                    The darkness is absolute when headlamps are off. Several miners are showing signs of panic. You have about 20 hours of battery life total across all headlamps. Below are 10 items available in your refuge area.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 for underground survival. Consider air quality, morale, signaling rescuers, and conserving resources for 7 days.
content.progressText: Calculating underground survival needs... Stay calm and think clearly.

expertPriorities: Air quality monitoring is critical - bad air kills without warning
Preserve battery power - total darkness causes severe psychological stress
Establish communication with surface to coordinate rescue
Maintain morale and prevent panic in confined space
Ration all resources for extended entrapment

items.name: Multi-gas detector
items.description: Monitors oxygen, methane, and carbon monoxide
items.explanation: Essential for detecting deadly gases. Bad air kills before you notice.

items.name: Mine rescue phone system
items.explanation: Direct communication with surface coordinates rescue and maintains morale.

items.name: Spare headlamp batteries (40 hours)
items.explanation: Light is sanity underground. Darkness causes panic and accidents.

items.name: Steel pipes and hammer
items.explanation: Sound travels through rock. Helps rescuers locate your exact position.

items.name: Water storage containers
items.description: Clean containers for collecting drip water
items.explanation: Captures safe drinking water. Dehydration impairs judgment quickly.

items.name: Mine first aid kit
items.explanation: Treats injuries and contains sedatives for panic attacks.

items.name: Emergency blankets (6)
items.explanation: Prevents hypothermia in damp conditions and treats shock.

items.name: Energy bars (3 days supply)
items.explanation: Maintains energy but humans can survive weeks without food.

items.name: Chalk and spray paint
items.explanation: Prevents getting lost if exploring for exits. Mostly psychological benefit.

items.name: Playing cards
items.explanation: Helps pass time but uses precious light. Better to conserve energy.

content.gameSubtitle: Underwater Emergency Training ‚Ä¢ Deep Sea Rescue Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
Your deep sea diving bell has lost power and buoyancy control at 300 feet depth. The surface support vessel was hit by a rogue wave and communications are down. You and three other commercial divers are trapped in the bell with limited resources.

                    The emergency ballast release has failed. Water temperature is 38¬∞F (3¬∞C). You have approximately 48 hours of emergency life support, but hypothermia is an immediate threat. The bell is slowly sinking and has settled on a ledge at 320 feet.

                    Surface crews are working to restore systems, but rough seas are hampering efforts. Emergency ascent without decompression would be fatal. You must survive until the backup dive team can reach you, estimated at 12-24 hours. You have access to 10 emergency items.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 for deep sea survival. Consider life support, thermal protection, emergency ascent risks, and communication.
content.dragInstructionsText: Prioritize for extreme underwater emergency. Pressure is building!
content.progressText: Analyzing deep sea survival priorities... Every decision is critical.

expertPriorities: Breathing gas management is absolutely critical - no air means death in minutes
Thermal protection prevents hypothermia which impairs judgment fatally
Communication with surface coordinates rescue and prevents panic
Decompression sickness prevention during any emergency ascent
Carbon dioxide buildup is as dangerous as low oxygen

items.name: CO2 scrubber cartridges
items.description: Removes carbon dioxide from breathing air
items.explanation: CO2 buildup kills faster than oxygen depletion. Absolutely critical.

items.name: Emergency heating packs
items.explanation: Prevents hypothermia which causes fatal decision-making errors.

items.name: Emergency through-water comms
items.explanation: Only way to coordinate rescue and report life support status.

items.name: Emergency oxygen bottles
items.description: Pure O2 for 12 hours (careful mixing required)
items.explanation: Extends life support but requires careful mixing to avoid oxygen toxicity.

items.name: Thermal survival suits
items.explanation: Reduces heat loss dramatically. Can double survival time in cold.

items.name: Depth and pressure gauges
items.description: Monitors bell depth and internal pressure
items.explanation: Critical for any emergency ascent planning and decompression.

items.name: Underwater emergency flares
items.explanation: Helps rescue divers locate bell in murky water.

items.name: Fresh water (2 gallons)
items.explanation: Prevents dehydration which worsens decompression sickness risk.

items.name: Diving medical kit
items.explanation: Treats pressure injuries but prevention is more critical.

items.name: Emergency tool kit
items.explanation: Limited use in catastrophic failures. Better to conserve oxygen.

content.gameSubtitle: Space Emergency Training ‚Ä¢ Zero-G Survival Protocol
content.emergencyScenario:
Your asteroid mining station on Asteroid 2029-TX has suffered a catastrophic solar panel failure during a solar storm. Main power is offline, and you're operating on emergency batteries with 72 hours of power remaining. You and your crew of four are 2.5 AU from Earth.

                    The station is slowly losing pressure through micro-fractures. Internal temperature is dropping as heating systems fail. You're in zero gravity, and the asteroid's rotation is causing disorienting day/night cycles every 3 hours. Communication with Earth has a 25-minute delay each way.

                    A rescue ship was dispatched immediately but will take 7-10 days to reach you. Your survival depends on managing limited resources in the harsh environment of space. You have access to 10 emergency items from the mining station's supplies.
content.instructionsText: Rank items 1-10 for space survival. Consider life support, power management, pressure retention, and maintaining crew sanity in isolation.
content.dragInstructionsText: Prioritize for deep space survival. Houston, we need solutions!
content.progressText: Computing survival priorities... In space, every resource is precious.

expertPriorities: Pressure retention is critical - even small leaks are fatal over time
Power management determines life support duration
CO2 scrubbing is as important as oxygen supply
Psychological factors in isolation can be as deadly as system failures
Redundancy in all critical systems - space offers no second chances

items.name: Emergency hull sealant
items.explanation: Stops pressure loss immediately. No atmosphere means death in seconds.

items.name: Portable battery packs
items.explanation: Extends life support operation. Power is life in space.

items.name: CO2 scrubber cartridges
items.explanation: CO2 poisoning occurs before oxygen depletion. Critical for survival.

items.name: Emergency heating units
items.explanation: Prevents freezing. Electronics and humans fail in extreme cold.

items.name: Water recycling unit
items.explanation: Extends water supply dramatically. Dehydration is fatal in days.

items.name: Emergency beacon
items.explanation: Helps rescue ship locate station precisely in vast space.

items.name: Emergency rations
items.explanation: Maintains crew health but less critical than air and water.

items.name: Entertainment tablets
items.explanation: Maintains psychological health. Isolation madness is real danger.

items.name: Space medicine kit
items.explanation: Treats space-specific ailments but prevention is key.

items.name: EVA repair tools
items.explanation: Risky to use. EVAs consume resources and risk suit punctures.
